document_title: Ionizing Radiation Stimulates Expression of Pro-Osteoclastogenic Genes in Marrow and Skeletal Tissue
summary_full: This study investigates the molecular mechanisms behind rapid bone loss induced by ionizing radiation, relevant to radiotherapy and long-duration space missions. Adult male mice were exposed to either gamma rays or heavy ions (iron). Gene expression in serum, marrow, and mineralized tissue was analyzed at various time points post-irradiation. Both types of radiation significantly increased the expression of Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor kappa-B Ligand (Rankl), a key cytokine for osteoclastogenesis, in marrow cells. This increase preceded and overlapped with elevated expression of other pro-osteoclastogenic and pro-inflammatory cytokines like monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (Mcp1) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (Tnf). The ratio of Rankl to its inhibitor Osteoprotegerin (Opg) also increased, indicating a pro-resorption balance. Expression of the antioxidant transcription factor Nfe2l2 correlated with osteoclast-related genes. Radiation exposure also increased a serum marker of bone resorption (tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase) and led to a measurable decrease in cancellous bone volume within a week. The findings suggest that total body irradiation triggers temporal elevations in genes related to bone resorption and osteoclastogenesis, contributing to rapid bone deterioration.
key_findings: Total body irradiation (gamma or heavy ion) significantly increases the expression of pro-osteoclastogenic genes, particularly Rankl, in bone marrow and skeletal tissue.
Elevated Rankl expression precedes and coincides with increased levels of other pro-osteoclastogenic cytokines (Mcp1, Tnf, Il6) and a pro-resorption balance (Rankl/Opg ratio).
Radiation exposure leads to increased serum levels of tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRACP 5b), a marker of bone resorption.
Cancellous bone loss (16% decrement in bone volume) was observed within one week following 2 Gy iron irradiation.

Expression of the antioxidant transcription factor Nfe2l2 showed a strong positive correlation with several osteoclast-related genes, suggesting a link between oxidative stress response and osteoclastogenesis.
The observed molecular changes in gene expression occurred prior to the manifestation of significant bone loss.
future_research_fields: Investigating the role of Nfe2l2-mediated antioxidant pathways in mitigating radiation-induced bone loss.
Exploring therapeutic strategies to counteract the pro-osteoclastogenic effects of radiation.
Examining the impact of different radiation dose rates and cumulative doses on bone microarchitecture and molecular signaling.
Further elucidating the interplay between inflammatory cytokines and osteoclastogenesis in the context of radiation exposure.
Assessing the long-term skeletal consequences of space radiation exposure.

conclusions: Total body irradiation, whether from gamma rays or heavy ions, induces temporal elevations in genes associated with bone resorption and osteoclastogenesis within marrow and mineralized tissues. These molecular changes, including increased Rankl and other pro-inflammatory cytokines, precede and likely account for the rapid and progressive deterioration of cancellous bone microarchitecture observed after radiation exposure.
impact_statement: This study reveals key molecular mechanisms by which ionizing radiation causes rapid bone loss, crucial for understanding risks to astronauts on long space missions and patients undergoing radiotherapy.
